At-a-Glance: Wax moths destroy stored comb and exploit weak colonies. The fix is proactive hygiene and smart storage.
Why it Matters: Drawn comb is a valuable asset; losing it sets colonies back and increases management workload.
Step-by-Step: 1) Keep colonies strong; unite weak units before autumn. 2) Retire old blackened combs; scrape burr/propolis where moths hide. 3) For storage: freeze frames to kill eggs/larvae, then store cool, bright, and ventilated. 4) Inspect stores periodically; respond early to any webbing.
Seasonality & Climate: In cooler climates, winter chill helps; in warm climates use freezing/heat treatment and airflow to deter infestations year-round.
Common Pitfalls: Dark, stagnant sheds invite moths; sealed stacks without prep let larvae flourish; leaving excessive empty comb on colonies late season attracts invasion.
Tools & Materials: Freezer or controlled heat, breathable storage, occasional pheromone/sticky monitoring traps; optional biological/approved chemical protectants where legal.
